title: 109_s1352
content: The Act titled "Improved Workplace and Community Transition Training for Incarcerated Youth Offenders Act of 2005" amends Section 821 of the Higher Education Amendments of 1998 to provide grants to states for enhanced training programs for incarcerated youth offenders. Congress finds that a significant portion of the prison population is young and lacks education, with a decrease in educational programs for inmates despite their proven effectiveness in reducing recidivism. Inmates released in 1999 served an average of 29 months for their current offense. In 2001, 592,000 offenders were released from State prison, with an average age of 34 years. Approximately 62 percent of State prisoners will be rearrested within 3 years, but participation in education programs while incarcerated reduces recidivism by 10 percent. Approximately 10 percent lower recidivism rate for youth offenders with education and training during incarceration. Intense supervision, support, and counseling needed post-release for effective reintegration. Grant program established by the Secretary of Education to assist youth offenders in acquiring literacy and job skills. Definition of youth offender as under 35 years old in State prison. The Secretary of Education has established a grant program to help youth offenders acquire literacy, job skills, and postsecondary education while in prison. State correctional education agencies must submit proposals for youth offender programs to be eligible for grants. The proposal for a youth offender program includes identifying the scope of the problem, listing educational institutions providing services, cooperating agencies for related services, and specific performance objectives and evaluation methods. The youth offender program proposal must include specific and quantified student outcome measures, program completion criteria, knowledge and skill attainment assessment methods, and employment attainment data. The youth offender program proposal must include specific student outcome measures, program completion criteria, knowledge and skill assessment methods, employment data, integration with existing correctional education programs, utilization of technology, and selection criteria for eligible youth offenders. Each State correctional education agency receiving a grant must report annually to the Secretary on evaluation results, objectives, and performance measures for participating students. The State correctional education agency receiving a grant must report annually to the Secretary on evaluation results, objectives, and performance measures for participating students. Youth offenders eligible for the program must be 35 years of age or younger and eligible for release within 5 years. The grant funds can be used for tuition, books, essential materials, career development, substance abuse counseling, parenting skills training, and health education. The State correctional education agency must provide educational services to youth offenders for up to 5 years, with the option for 1 year of graduate education or remedial services. High-tech applications should be used in program development. Funds must be allocated appropriately. The Secretary will allocate funds to each State based on the number of eligible students, with $30,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 2006 and additional funds for the following years.
